model_completion: Stroke is a medical emergency that occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted. This can happen due to a blood clot blocking a blood vessel in the brain or a blood vessel in the brain breaking open and causing bleeding. Common symptoms of stroke include sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm or leg, especially on one side of the body; sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding speech; sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes; sudden trouble walking, dizziness or loss of balance; and sudden severe headache.

Stroke is diagnosed based on the signs and symptoms that the patient experiences. If a person has sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm or leg, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, trouble seeing in one or both eyes, dizziness, headache or confusion, these are all signs of stroke. It is important to seek immediate medical attention if any of these symptoms occur.

Stroke is a medical emergency that needs immediate attention. If a person is experiencing any signs of stroke, such as weakness, numbness or difficulty speaking, they need to call 911 immediately. Once at the hospital, the doctor will determine what kind of stroke the patient is having and administer appropriate treatment. The goal of treatment is to restore blood flow to the brain and minimize damage. This can be done through medications, surgery or both.

Stroke is the third leading cause of death in the United States, according to the American Heart Association. It occurs when a blood vessel in the brain becomes blocked or bursts, depriving the brain of oxygen. There are many risk factors for stroke, including high blood pressure, smoking, obesity, diabetes, high cholesterol, atrial fibrillation, family history and age.

An ischemic stroke occurs when a blood vessel in the brain becomes blocked by a blood clot. This prevents oxygen from reaching the brain, causing damage to the brain cells. A hemorrhagic stroke occurs when a blood vessel in the brain ruptures, allowing blood to leak into the brain. This can cause pressure within the skull and damage to the surrounding brain tissue.

Stroke is the third leading cause of death in the United States, according to the American Heart Association. It occurs when a blood vessel in the brain becomes blocked or bursts, depriving the brain of oxygen. There are many factors that increase a person's risk of having a stroke, including high blood pressure, smoking, obesity, diabetes, high cholesterol and atrial fibrillation. People can reduce their risk of having a stroke by maintaining a healthy weight, eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly, not smoking and managing any chronic conditions such as high blood pressure, diabetes and high cholesterol.

Insomnia is defined as having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep. It can be short term or long term, and it can affect anyone at any age. Some of the most common symptoms of insomnia include difficulty falling asleep, waking up frequently during the night, waking up too early in the morning, daytime sleepiness and fatigue. Insomnia can be caused by many things, including stress, anxiety, depression, certain medications, poor sleep habits, medical conditions and substance abuse.

Insomnia is diagnosed based on the patient's history and physical examination. The doctor will ask about the patient's sleep habits and any problems they are having sleeping. The doctor will also perform a physical examination to rule out any underlying medical conditions that could be causing the insomnia. If the patient is experiencing insomnia due to another medical condition, such as depression, anxiety or chronic pain, the doctor will treat that condition first.

Insomnia is defined as having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep. It can be caused by many things, including stress, anxiety, depression, certain medications, poor sleep habits and medical conditions such as asthma, arthritis, acid reflux and chronic pain. Treatment for insomnia depends on the underlying cause. If the problem is related to a medical condition, treating the condition may help improve sleep. If the problem is due to stress, anxiety or depression, counseling or therapy may be helpful. Cognitive behavioral therapy is another option.

Insomnia is defined as having difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep for at least three nights per week for at least three months. It is not normal to have trouble sleeping every once in a while. Insomnia can affect your daytime functioning and make you feel tired and irritable. If you have insomnia, you may find yourself struggling to fall asleep, waking up frequently throughout the night or waking up too early in the morning. You may also experience fatigue during the day.

Insomnia is defined as having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep. It is a very common problem, affecting about 30 percent of adults at some point in their lives. Risk factors for insomnia include stress, anxiety, depression, poor sleep habits, certain medical conditions and substance use.

Insomnia is a sleep disorder that affects millions of Americans. It is characterized by difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, and it can cause fatigue, irritability, depression and other problems. Lifestyle changes can help reduce insomnia symptoms, such as going to bed at the same time every night, avoiding naps during the day, limiting caffeine intake and avoiding alcohol and nicotine. Other helpful tips include exercising regularly, practicing relaxation techniques and avoiding large meals before bedtime.

Breast cancer is the second most common cancer among women in the United States, according to the American Cancer Society. It is estimated that 231,840 new cases of invasive breast cancer will be diagnosed in 2015, and about 40,290 women will die from the disease. Early detection is key to successful treatment of breast cancer, so it is important to know what to look for. The most common sign of breast cancer is a lump or thickening in the breast or underarm area. Other signs include swelling, redness or dimpling of the skin; nipple discharge; and pain in the breast or nipple area.

Breast cancer is diagnosed using a combination of imaging tests and biopsies. Imaging tests used to diagnose breast cancer include mammography, ultrasound, MRI and bone scans. These tests help determine if there is any suspicious tissue in the breast. If there is, a biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis. During a biopsy, a sample of tissue is removed from the breast and sent to a lab for analysis.

Breast cancer is treated with surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy and hormone therapy. The type of treatment depends on the stage of the cancer, the age of the patient and the general health of the patient. Surgery is used to remove the tumor and some surrounding tissue. Chemotherapy uses drugs to kill cancer cells throughout the body. Radiation therapy uses high-energy rays to kill cancer cells. Hormone therapy blocks the effects of hormones that promote cancer growth.

Breast cancer is the second most common cancer among women in the United States, according to the American Cancer Society. While there are many risk factors associated with breast cancer, some of the most significant ones include being female, having a family history of breast cancer, being older than 50, having dense breasts and having a history of radiation exposure to the chest. Other risk factors include obesity, alcohol consumption, smoking, hormone replacement therapy and not having children.

Lifestyle factors such as maintaining a healthy weight, exercising regularly, limiting alcohol consumption and not smoking can all help reduce the risk of developing breast cancer. Women who are at high risk for breast cancer due to family history or genetic mutations may benefit from starting hormone therapy early.

Breast cancer can affect a woman's daily life in many ways. Some women experience physical changes such as lumps, swelling, redness or discharge from the nipples. Other women may notice changes in their breasts, such as dimpling or thickening of the skin. Women may also experience fatigue, weight loss, shortness of breath, nausea and vomiting. In addition, some women may experience emotional changes, such as anxiety, depression, fear and anger.

Serotonin syndrome occurs when there is too much serotonin in the body. This can happen when a person takes certain medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs). It can also occur when a person takes these medications along with another drug that increases serotonin levels, such as tramadol, dextromethorphan or tryptophan. Symptoms of serotonin syndrome include agitation, confusion, hallucinations, fever, sweating, shivering, muscle rigidity, tremors, rapid heartbeat, nausea and vomiting. If a person experiences any of these symptoms, they should seek immediate medical attention.

Serotonin syndrome is diagnosed based on the symptoms that a person experiences. It is important to note that not everyone who takes a medication that increases serotonin levels will develop serotonin syndrome. In fact, only about 1 percent of people who take these medications will experience this condition. If a person is experiencing symptoms of serotonin syndrome, such as agitation, confusion, fever, sweating, tremors, muscle rigidity, nausea and vomiting, they should seek immediate medical attention.

Treatment for serotonin syndrome includes stopping the medications that are causing the problem and providing supportive care.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of disorders that affect the intestines and cause inflammation. IBD can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, but it most commonly affects the colon and rectum. Symptoms of IBD include diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, fatigue and fever. Some people may experience bloody stools, rectal bleeding, rectal pain and vomiting.

Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, while ulcerative colitis only affects the colon. The exact cause of IBD is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

Cirrhosis is a chronic liver disease that occurs when scar tissue replaces normal liver tissue. It is typically caused by long-term damage to the liver, such as alcoholism or viral hepatitis. The most common symptom of cirrhosis is jaundice, or yellowing of the skin and eyes. Other symptoms include fatigue, weakness, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, abdominal swelling, itching, easy bruising and bleeding, and confusion.

Cirrhosis is diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical examination. A doctor will ask about the patient's symptoms and perform a physical examination to look for signs of liver damage. In addition, the doctor will likely order blood tests to check for elevated levels of certain enzymes and proteins that indicate liver damage. These tests can help determine the stage of cirrhosis.

Cirrhosis is a chronic liver disease that occurs when scar tissue replaces normal liver tissue. It is typically caused by long-term alcohol abuse, but it can also be caused by viral hepatitis, fatty liver disease, autoimmune diseases and certain inherited disorders. Treatment depends on the underlying cause of the disease. If the cause is alcohol abuse, the patient must stop drinking. If the cause is viral hepatitis, the patient will need to take antiviral medications. If the cause is fatty liver disease, the patient will need to lose weight and follow a healthy diet.

Cirrhosis is a chronic liver disease that occurs when scar tissue replaces normal liver tissue. This scarring prevents the liver from working properly, and it can eventually lead to liver failure. The liver performs many important functions, including filtering the blood, producing bile and storing vitamins and minerals. When the liver is not able to perform these functions, the body cannot break down nutrients and remove waste products.

Lifestyle changes can help individuals manage cirrhosis, which is scarring of the liver. These changes include eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly, drinking alcohol in moderation and not using illegal drugs. The most common symptom of kidney cancer is blood in the urine. Other symptoms include flank pain, fever, fatigue, weight loss and decreased appetite. These symptoms can be caused by many different conditions, so it is important to see a doctor if any of these symptoms are present.

Kidney cancer is diagnosed using imaging tests such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI and biopsy. These tests help determine the size and location of the tumor, as well as whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. Once the diagnosis is made, the physician will discuss treatment options with the patient.

Treatment for kidney cancer depends on the stage of the cancer and the overall health of the patient. If the cancer is localized, meaning it hasn't spread beyond the kidney, surgery is the primary treatment option. If the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes, radiation therapy may be used in addition to surgery. If the cancer has spread to distant organs, chemotherapy is the main treatment option.

Kidney cancer is classified into four stages based on the size of the tumor and whether it has spread beyond the kidney. Stage 1 is the earliest stage, and the tumor is less than 7 centimeters in diameter and has not spread beyond the kidney. Stage 2 is slightly larger, and the tumor is between 7 and 10 centimeters in diameter. In stage 3, the tumor is larger than 10 centimeters and has spread to nearby lymph nodes. In stage 4, the tumor has spread to distant organs such as the liver, lungs or bones.

Kidney cancer is caused by uncontrolled growth of cells in the kidneys. It is not known what causes these cells to grow out of control, but risk factors include smoking, obesity, high blood pressure and family history.

There are many things that can increase the risk of developing kidney cancer, including smoking, obesity, high blood pressure, family history and exposure to certain chemicals. It is important to talk to your doctor about any risk factors you may have and what steps you can take to reduce your risk.

Yellow fever is a viral infection that is transmitted through mosquito bites. It is found in tropical and subtropical regions of South America and Africa. The initial symptoms of yellow fever include fever, headache, muscle aches, nausea and vomiting. These symptoms last about three to six days, and then the person develops jaundice, which is why the disease is named "yellow fever." Jaundice is characterized by yellowing of the skin and eyes. Other symptoms include fatigue, abdominal pain, loss of appetite and dark urine.

Yellow fever is transmitted through the bite of an infected mosquito. It is found in tropical and subtropical regions of South America and Africa. In the United States, it is only found in rare cases in travelers returning from these areas.

Anxiety disorders are characterized by excessive worry and fear about everyday situations. These feelings can interfere with daily activities and cause significant distress. Common symptoms of anxiety disorders include restlessness, fatigue, irritability, muscle tension, difficulty concentrating and sleep problems. Some individuals may experience physical symptoms such as sweating, trembling, nausea, dizziness and rapid heartbeat.

Anxiety disorders are diagnosed based on the patient's symptoms and a physical examination. In addition, the doctor may perform tests to rule out other possible causes of the symptoms. These tests may include blood work, a chest X-ray, electrocardiogram (EKG) and possibly a CT scan or MRI.

Anxiety disorders are treated with a combination of psychotherapy and medication. Psychotherapy can help individuals learn coping skills and develop strategies to manage their anxiety. Medications can help reduce the symptoms of anxiety, such as panic attacks, and can be used alone or in conjunction with psychotherapy.

Anxiety disorders vary in severity and symptoms. Some people experience only occasional anxiety, while others have chronic anxiety that interferes with daily activities. Common symptoms include excessive worry, fear, restlessness, irritability, muscle tension, difficulty concentrating and sleep problems.

Anxiety disorders are very common, affecting about 18 percent of adults in the United States at some point in their lives. While there are many possible causes of anxiety disorders, research suggests that genetic factors play a role. In addition, certain environmental factors, such as stressful events, may trigger the development of an anxiety disorder.

Anxiety disorders are very common, affecting about 40 million adults in the United States each year. Fortunately, there are many effective treatments available for anxiety disorders, including psychotherapy, medication and self-help techniques. Psychotherapy is a good option for those who prefer not to take medication or who want to learn coping skills to help manage their anxiety. Cognitive behavioral therapy is a type of psychotherapy that helps individuals identify and change negative thoughts and behaviors that contribute to anxiety. Medication is another option for managing anxiety. Antidepressants are commonly used to treat anxiety disorders, and benzodiazepines are sometimes prescribed for short-term relief of anxiety symptoms.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a disorder that affects the large intestine. It is characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea and/or constipation. IBS is very common, affecting 10 to 20 percent of the population at some point in their lives.

Irritable bowel syndrome is diagnosed based on a person's symptoms and a physical examination. In some cases, a doctor may perform tests such as a colonoscopy or endoscopy to rule out other conditions. These tests can help determine if the symptoms are due to irritable bowel syndrome or another condition.

Irritable bowel syndrome is a disorder that affects the large intestine and causes symptoms such as cramping, bloating, gas, diarrhea and constipation. These symptoms can range from mild to severe and can last anywhere from a few days to several months at a time. Other symptoms include nausea, vomiting, fatigue and headaches. It is important to note that these symptoms can be similar to those of other conditions, so it is important to see a doctor to determine the cause of the symptoms.

There are many different treatments available for irritable bowel syndrome, or IBS. These include lifestyle changes, such as eating smaller meals throughout the day, avoiding certain foods and drinking plenty of fluids. Medications are also available, including antispasmodics, antidiarrheals and anti-anxiety medications. If these treatments don't work, a doctor may prescribe a psychiatric medication to help reduce anxiety and stress.

Altitude sickness occurs when a person ascends too quickly to a high altitude without allowing his or her body time to adjust. Symptoms of altitude sickness include headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, fatigue, shortness of breath and insomnia. These symptoms usually start within 12 to 24 hours of arriving at a higher altitude. If these symptoms continue for more than 24 hours, a person should seek medical attention.

It is important to gradually increase your elevation when traveling to higher altitudes. Altitude sickness is treated by moving to a lower elevation. If this isn't possible, medications can be used to help alleviate symptoms. These include acetazolamide, dexamethasone and nifedipine. In some cases, oxygen therapy may be necessary.

Alopecia areata is a condition that causes hair loss on the scalp and elsewhere on the body. It is not known what causes alopecia areata, but it is thought to be an autoimmune disorder. In some cases, the hair loss is temporary and reversible, while in others, the hair loss is permanent. There is no cure for alopecia areata, but there are treatments available to help manage the condition. These include topical creams, steroid injections, oral medications and light therapy.

Chronic kidney disease is a progressive condition that occurs when the kidneys lose function over time. It is often asymptomatic until the later stages, at which point individuals may experience fatigue, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, muscle cramps, swelling, high blood pressure and changes in urination.

Chronic kidney disease is diagnosed through a simple blood test that measures the level of creatinine in the blood. Creatinine is a waste product produced by muscle metabolism. When the kidneys are not functioning properly, creatinine levels rise. Other tests that may be used to confirm the diagnosis include a urinalysis, ultrasound and kidney biopsy.

Chronic kidney disease is a progressive condition that affects the kidneys' ability to filter waste products from the body. It is typically diagnosed when the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) falls below 60 milliliters per minute. Treatment depends on the stage of the disease and the underlying cause. In early stages, treatment focuses on slowing the progression of the disease and reducing the risk of developing end-stage renal disease. This can be done through lifestyle changes such as eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly and quitting smoking. Medications may also be prescribed to help control high blood pressure and reduce protein in the urine.

Chronic kidney disease occurs when the kidneys are not able to filter waste products from the body effectively. This can happen due to damage to the kidneys, such as from high blood pressure, diabetes or glomerulonephritis. It can also occur due to a blockage in the urinary tract, which prevents the kidneys from filtering properly.

Stage 1 is defined as having a creatinine level between 1.0 and 1.4 milligrams per deciliter of blood. Chronic kidney disease is a progressive condition that can be managed with lifestyle changes and medications. Pellagra is a nerve disorder that results from a deficiency of vitamin B3, also known as niacin. It is characterized by four main symptoms: dermatitis, dementia, diarrhea and weakness. Dermatitis is a rash that appears on the face, neck, hands and feet. It is red and scaly and can be very itchy. Depression and confusion are common symptoms of dementia. Varicose veins are enlarged, swollen veins that appear blue or purple in color. These veins are most commonly found on the legs and feet, although they can occur anywhere in the body. Varicose veins are caused by weakened valves in the veins, which allow blood to flow backwards. This results in increased pressure in the veins, causing them to bulge outward. While varicose veins are not typically a serious medical problem, they can cause discomfort and pain.

Varicose veins are diagnosed based on the appearance of the veins. During an examination, the physician will look at the legs and feet to determine if there are any visible veins. Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) is a group of symptoms that women experience just prior to menstruation. These symptoms can range from mild to severe and can affect a woman's physical and emotional health. Common symptoms include breast tenderness, bloating, fatigue, headaches, irritability, depression, anxiety, insomnia, constipation and weight gain. Some women may also experience acne, joint pain, muscle aches and cramps, and changes in appetite.
